text:
Q: How to restrict user interaction on Android tablet in a Flutter app A:

Yes, you can download their project first before using it in your own project.

Q: Getting ORA-00933 with EF Core when running queries A:

There is no doubt, naming your column as INT is very bad idea, as that is a reserved keyword.

This is not an answer but alternate to avoid this conflict.

Since changing the column name is not possible, the safest is to use a database view.

CREATE OR REPLACE VIEW NEW_TABLE AS
SELECT "INT" AS ID, OTHER_COLUMN
FROM YOUR_TABLE;

Then map EF Core to NEW_TABLE and use Id normally. No more reserved keyword conflicts.

This way, you would not have any conflicts further.

Q: cannot append index array to associative array sorts A:

From the provided example I would say your program always have been broken: it declares variable sorts as an associative array, then assigns a value to it which converts it into an indexed array.

Actually, this conversion happens in the ksh93 version of Aix6, but doesn't happen in the ksh93 version of Aix7 (Version M 93t+ 2009-05-01 in my case), it produces an error message.

For a quick fix, remove the declare -A sorts line from your code. (Or, if this is not the actual code, please provide more details.)

PS: the ksh93 version provided by Aix6 is as old as it doesn't even have a version number.

PPS: this code works in different ksh93 (and bash) versions:

typeset -A ascarr
myval='[app le]="Ap fel"'
eval "ascarr=($myval)"
set | grep ascarr

result:
ascarr=(["app le"]="Ap fel" )

Q: Microsoft SMTP Email with client_Credentials oauth token: 554 5.2.252 SendAsDenied when from_address is of external domain(other than microsoft) A:

I am surprised it ever worked for you. M365 won't let you spoof the sender. The best you can do is specify one of the proxy SMTP addresses of the mailbox (even if it is not the default SMTP address).

Q: R - Subset rows in data.table using the columns named in a variable with inequalities (< 0, > 0) A: 
f0 <- function(x,c1,c2,verbose=FALSE) {
  x[v1 < 0 | v2 < 0 | v3 > 0 | v4 > 0,
    env = list(v1=c1[1], v2=c1[2], v3=c2[1], v4=c2[2]),
    verbose=verbose]
}

f0(dttest,lats,longs,verbose=T)

# Argument 'i' after substitute: `From Lat` < 0 | `To Lat` < 0 | `From Long` > 0 | `To Long` > 0
#        Name From Lat    To Lat From Long   To Long
#      <char>    <num>     <num>     <num>     <num>
# 1: Stream 1 36.30239 -84.51243  35.35329  35.64342
# 2: Stream 2 35.26466  36.31149  35.19410 -86.14513

and see ?data.table for the documentation of the i parameter.

Edit: generalising with env

What's the best method to replicate dttest[From Lat< 0 |To Lat< 0 |From Long> 0 |To Long > 0] using the columns named in a variable?

If that specific expression is all you need then you can't do better than the solution above, but @r2evans has questioned whether this can be generalised to arbitrary numbers of columns (as 2 of the 3 other answers have chosen to do). He claims that env is not suited to variadic references (i.e. arguments captured by ...).

Three options for generalising the solution are:

[1] Do what the other 3 solutions do, i.e. build the logical vector "on the side" and then pass it into the i of dttest[i], i.e. <create logical vector> |> dttest[i=_]. These solutions do the variable injection into j in a side-calculation, using good old-fashioned .. or .SDcols.

Take @s_baldur's answer, which is the most preferred of the 3: it creates two new data.tables of the selected columns (selected as vectors of names passed into j using the "one-frame-up" symbol ..), and calls pmin or pmax on them via do.call(), which treats them as lists of arguments (inherently, all data frames are lists of vectors).

f1 <- function(x,c1,c2) {
  x[do.call(pmin, x[, ..c1]) < 0 | do.call(pmax, x[, ..c2]) > 0]
}

[2] Use env to compute the same thing but directly inside i, i.e. dttest[i=<create logical vector from columns>]. The problem with [1] is that the columns of the side-objects (e.g. dttest[,..lats]) are full copies, not shallow references, which is inefficient. But we can take this do.call() idea and combine it with the automatic enlisting behaviour of env described in the programming vignette (section "Substituting lists of arbitrary length").

f2 <- function(x,c1,c2,verbose=FALSE) {
  x[do.call(pmin, c1) < 0 | do.call(pmax, c2) > 0,
    env=list(c1=as.list(c1), c2=as.list(c2)),
    verbose=verbose]
}

This way we get the goodness of @s_baldur's solution in the frame of one [.data.table call, working directly on the columns without intermediate copies.

Here is the verbose=TRUE output of f2 on a modified example (with an extra column in longs), showing what the i argument resolves to after substitution:

dttest2 <- copy(dttest)[,`Other Long`:=c(-1,1,-1,1)]
lats2 <- lats
longs2 <- c(longs,"Other Long")

f2(dttest2,lats2,longs2,verbose=T)
# Argument 'i' after substitute: do.call(pmin, list(`From Lat`, `To Lat`)) < 0
# | do.call(pmax, list(`From Long`, `To Long`, `Other Long`)) > 0

This pattern (do.call() on a list call that substitute2 creates automatically if we pass the column names into env via as.list) seems to me a good general way of injecting into ....

[3] Construct a long OR expression flexibly, and likewise inject it with env. This option is hairier but doable using methods like those illustrated in the final section of the vignette ("Substitution of a complex query"). I actually did it for this answer, but it doesn't perform as well as [2] on many columns, so I won't show the code or include it in the benchmarks.

f3(dttest2,lats2,longs2,verbose=T)
# Argument 'i' after substitute: (`From Lat` < 0) | (`To Lat` < 0)
# | (`From Long` > 0) | (`To Long` > 0) | (`Other Long` > 0)
Performance

Outputs are from bench::mark() with check=TRUE.

make_data <- \(n,nlat,nlong) {
  lats <- letters[1:nlat]
  longs <- LETTERS[1:nlong]
  data.table(name=paste("Stream", seq.int(n))) |>
    _[, (lats) := as.data.table(0.98 + matrix(runif(n*nlat),nrow=n))] |>
    _[, (longs) := as.data.table(-0.98 + matrix(runif(n*nlong),nrow=n))]
}

dt <- make_data(n=1e6L,nlat=10L,nlong=20L)

# original question (2 lats, 2 longs)
lats <- letters[1:2]
longs <- LETTERS[1:2]

#            expression median_ms mem_MiB rel_t rel_mem n_itr n_gc
# 1 f0(dt, lats, longs)        29      40  1.00    1.00   100    0
# 2 f1(dt, lats, longs)        38      71  1.33    1.76    98    2
# 3 f2(dt, lats, longs)        33      40  1.16    1.00    99    1

# 10 lats, 20 longs (and much larger result)
lats <- intersect(names(dt), letters)
longs <- intersect(names(dt), LETTERS)

           expression median_ms mem_MiB rel_t rel_mem n_itr n_gc
# 1 f1(dt, lats, longs)       185     339  1.22    3.07    93    7
# 2 f2(dt, lats, longs)       152     110  1.00    1.00    97    3

bench::mark() doesn't capture data.table's non-R C-level allocations, but the difference in memory usage between f1 (@s_baldur as-is) and f2 (same but using env) reflects R-level copies and is equal to the object sizes (not shown) of the intermediate deep-copy data.tables.

Conclusion: the "best method" is env. You can either use f0 (substitute into a fixed expression) or the f2 version of @s_baldur's very good general solution that uses pmin/pmax logic (but substituting into i directly to avoid the inefficiency of working on copies).

Moral: env is the canonical way to program with data.table across i,j,(key)by and should be go-to. It is flexible and turns out to handle substitution into ... easily. We need to get our heads round it a bit more (this question has helped me a lot in that regard) and stop advocating inferior/inefficient situational workarounds based on older interfaces restricted to j.
